messageBody:
On 7/5/07, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> Kevin,
>
> Yep, that can be a pain. I've only gotten bit by it once every couple
> weeks, which is about half as often as I appreciate the fact that
> quick-fix on
>
> assertThat(myNewMethod(), is("abc"));
>
> creates
>
> String myNewMethod() {
> }
>
> so for me, hamcrest does optimize for the common case.
>
>

Thanks Davids,

My question was about 30% grumbling and 70% wondering if I was missing
something really obvious.

I too have been delighted when the quickfix gets the signature right and I
am (mostly) delighted by hamcrest in general...but there are enough rough
edges that I am not yet ready to love Hamcrest. Some days I just think, man,
it's just so much easier to type assertEquals :-(

We talked about the static import thing before - neither Eclipse nor
IntelliJ does a good job yet of auto importing static methods - and I worked
around that by creating an IntelliJ template for tests that imports
everything I need and creates a stub method so that 'optimize imports'
doesn't immediately optimize them away.

I think more complete 'file' & 'live' templates will smooth over some of the
rough edges.

Here's what i currently have for IntelliJ:

File | New | JUnit4 Test (enter 'MyType' for the name ) will create this:

package demo.spreadsheet.ui;

import org.junit.Before;
import org.junit.Test;
import static org.hamcrest.Matchers.*;
import static org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.*;

public class MyTypeTest {
MyType objectUnderTest;

@Before
public void setup() throws Exception {
objectUnderTest = new MyType();
}

@Test
public void firstTest() throws Exception {
assertThat(objectUnderTest.getState(), is(expectedValue));
}
}

Then

- F2 (go to next error), ALT-ENTER (quick fix) creates the type
- ALT-DOWN x2 goes to firstTest() which I rename
- F2 goes to getState() which I rename to be the result I am testing
- F2 goes to expectedValue which I edit
- then I rename objectUnderTest to something more appropriate

and I am ready to fill in the rest of the details of my test.

To create new test methods I have a 'live template' that triggers on 't4'
(for JUnit4 test) and gives me:

@Test
public void [methodname]() throws Exception {
assertThat([fieldname], is([value]));
}


Do other people use templates so heavily? Any other tips?

--
Kevin
